replies.msg:
I was reading the proposed NY Times ad and came across "meeting between Trump and Xi ..." I would have written "meeting between President Trump and President Xi." Just a little thing but there's nothing to gain by being disrespectful in a letter seen by millions, especially when you're the underdog and need as much sympathy and goodwill as you can get. In NYT news articles, they call everyone Mr., Ms or Mrs., including mass murderers. If you have a chance to meet with Carrie Lam, if you speak respectfully and calmly, at least she'll hear what you say (it probably won't change her mind), but if you scream and curse at her, she will just harden her position. The key thing is that personal feelings are less important than what's best for the movement. If you're sure you can crush the other side, you can act as rudely and aggressively as you like. But if the other side is so much more powerful, the only way to get some of what you want is through peaceful means (peaceful protests, negotiations, bringing public opinion to your side). For example, Martin Luther King had meetings with government officials (including President Johnson), whom he probably hated, while protesting their policies. You might hate the people of the other side, but having dialogs with them (in addition to other actions such as voting) might be in the best interest of the movement.
Another nitpick: I would also sign the ad with "The People of Hong Kong" (or Hongkong) instead of "Hongkongers." If Americans were writing such a letter, they would sign it with "The People of America" and not "Americans." It sounds better.

The protesters throwing eggs or pointing laser at the police are too young to think strategically. I'd like to ask someone who threw an egg that hit a policeman in the face, "How do you think that will help or hurt the cause you're fighting for? How would you feel if you were that policeman? When the order comes for the police to disperse or arrest protesters, do you think he and his fellow policemen will use more or less force?" A policeman following orders to push back protesters has a lot of discretion in how much and how hard to beat someone without punishment (almost always). Those eggs could cause some protesters to be more seriously injured than otherwise would have been, and tarnish the image of the movement. So little benefit (the egg throwers released some anger); such high costs potentially. I don't blame them too much, though. I also didn't think strategically about things when I was their age. It would be nice to have a mature leader help them see the big picture.

「香港人」是一種城市身份的確認，如「紐約客」（NewYorker）之於紐約，「倫敦人」（Londoner）之於倫敦。城市與生活於其中的人互相形塑，要有自己的文化特色、生活價值才配有一個城市稱號；能進入權威辭典視野，當然又要有一定的「國際性」。
